abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project is rated as
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and, both the Bank,
            and the Borrower's performances were satisfactory.
            Lessons suggest that: 1) an efficient management of local
            resources, and expenditures is critical for building
            creditworthiness of local communities and their investment
            programs, to further establish sound intergovernmental
            finance systems, with the appropriate incentives in the
            process of decentralization. However, the experience of this
            project indicates that a lot remains to be done to
            rationalize the allocation of powers, and responsibilities,
            between the Central and Local Governments, an issue to be
            addressed in future operations; 2) while the Communal
            Infrastructure Fund stands as a solid financial institution,
            following its restructuring, there is still the need to
            improve monitoring practices in post-evaluation of projects,
            to prevent risking funds, and future operations as well. In
            addition, environmental concerns were not fully integrated
            into the evaluation process, and it will need to be
            introduced in future routine operations; 3) although at
            appraisal, extensive training was included for strengthening
            the local governments' capacity, the component was
            dropped due to a reluctant Government to pursue the program
            as such. However, external financing could have been
            mobilized, and, training ensured at negotiations.
